dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Hey, B. So, we've been hearing a lot about China's oil futures market, right? The Shanghai INE.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey, B. So, we've been hearing a lot about China's oil futures market, right? The Shanghai I N E.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, A, absolutely. And, like, you see the headlines, the volume there is huge. It actually surpasses Brent and WTI in some ways.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, A, absolutely. And, like, you see the headlines, the volume there is huge. It actually surpasses Brent and W T I in some ways.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Of course the volume of trades on the Shanghai INE still lags behind that of the Brent oil contracts traded in London and the West Texas Intermediate oil futures traded in New York.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps] Right, so you'd think, "Oh, this is a big deal for the renminbi, right? Pushing its global presence."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, so you'd think, Oh, this is a big deal for the renminbi, right? Pushing its global presence.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, that's where it gets, uh, interesting. Our latest piece in The Asia-Pacific Journal actually argues the opposite.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, that's where it gets, uh, interesting. Our latest piece in The Asia-Pacific Journal actually argues the opposite.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh? Opposite how? I mean, big volume, Chinese currency... seems like a no-brainer.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh? Opposite how? I mean, big volume, Chinese currency... seems like a no-brainer.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Not so much. The thing is, multinational commodity traders, like a Glencore, they're kind of ignoring it. And, um, the pricing is totally different from Brent or WTI.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Not so much. The thing is, multinational commodity traders, like a Glencore, they're kind of ignoring it. And, um, the pricing is totally different from Brent or W T I.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Chinese oil futures contract is, however, being taken seriously by multinational commodity traders (like Glencore) and is priced in a manner that is comparable to the Brent and WTI indices.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: So, it's not really integrated into the global system then. But, what does that mean for the renminbi? My understanding was this was meant to internationalize it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, it's not really integrated into the global system then. But, what does that mean for the renminbi? My understanding was this was meant to internationalize it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that was the conventional wisdom. But the article suggests it could actually *weaken* Chinese capital markets and, get this, accelerate the dollarization of the oil market.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that was the conventional wisdom. But the article suggests it could actually weaken Chinese capital markets and, get this, accelerate the dollarization of the oil market.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This can be anticipated to strengthen Chinese capital markets and promote the renminbis internationalization or at least the progressive de-dollarization of the oil market.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: [puzzled] Wait, dollarization? How does a Chinese oil futures contract lead to *more* dollarization? That feels, uh, counter-intuitive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, dollarization? How does a Chinese oil futures contract lead to more dollarization? That feels, uh, counter-intuitive.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! It's because if fewer Chinese oil imports are priced in renminbi, then foreign suppliers, they don't have as much renminbi to then buy Chinese goods or bonds.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! It's because if fewer Chinese oil imports are priced in renminbi, then foreign suppliers, they don't have as much renminbi to then buy Chinese goods or bonds.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As more of Chinas oil imports come to be priced in its domestic currency, foreign suppliers will have more renminbi-denominated accounts with which they can purchase not only Chinese goods and services, but also Chinese government securities and bonds.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, that makes sense. So, it's not giving them a reason to hold RMB. And what about China's broader strategy? Didn't they, like, try to push the renminbi internationally for a while?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, that makes sense. So, it's not giving them a reason to hold R M B. And what about China's broader strategy? Didn't they, like, try to push the renminbi internationally for a while?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: They did, but then-governor Zhou Xiaochuan essentially abandoned the idea of the SDR, the IMF's Special Drawing Rights, as a rival to the dollar back in 2019. He saw it more as a development tool.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They did, but then-governor Zhou Xiaochuan essentially abandoned the idea of the S D R, the I M F's Special Drawing Rights, as a rival to the dollar back in twenty nineteen. He saw it more as a development tool.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Peoples Bank of Chinas then-governor, Zhou Xiaochuan, spelled out the strategy in an essay in 2009. With new allocations of SDRs to emerging industrial powers like China, the SDR, based on a basket of currencies including the renminbi, could serve not only as a development tool, but also as a means of international payment to rival the US dollar.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] So, even then, they weren't really trying to dethrone the dollar. And now, with these US tariffs and sanctions...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, even then, they weren't really trying to dethrone the dollar. And now, with these U S tariffs and sanctions...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Right. The article makes a pretty strong case that China's immediate objective isn't renminbi internationalization. It might actually be *dollarization* of the international system, partly to, uh, work around those very sanctions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. The article makes a pretty strong case that China's immediate objective isn't renminbi internationalization. It might actually be dollarization of the international system, partly to, uh, work around those very sanctions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If Chinas ultimate goals include internationalizing the renminbi, its more immediate objective, prompted in part by US tariffs or sanctions on China and other countries, is de-dollarization of the international system.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: But then, why would Russia and Iran, for example, sell oil to China but refuse payment in renminbi? Like, wouldn't they want an alternative to the dollar?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then, why would Russia and Iran, for example, sell oil to China but refuse payment in renminbi? Like, wouldn't they want an alternative to the dollar?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Both Russia and Iran, for example, are selling oil to China and accepting payment in renminbi, in response to actual or potential sanctions imposed on them by the US.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: You'd think so, wouldn't you? But, uh, they're often rejecting RMB. They have their own reasons, often linked to, like, not having much to import from China or other strategic considerations. It just shows the uphill battle for the renminbi.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You'd think so, wouldn't you? But, uh, they're often rejecting R M B. They have their own reasons, often linked to, like, not having much to import from China or other strategic considerations. It just shows the uphill battle for the renminbi.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Both Russia and Iran, for example, are selling oil to China and accepting payment in renminbi... They also have extensive imports from China, as well as other reasons for seeking strengthened ties.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So, effectively, China's actions, even its oil futures, might actually be reinforcing dollar hegemony rather than challenging it, and even their own companies prefer to avoid currency fluctuations with the dollar.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So, effectively, China's actions, even its oil futures, might actually be reinforcing dollar hegemony rather than challenging it, and even their own companies prefer to avoid currency fluctuations with the dollar.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: China no doubt views the emergence of renminbi-denominated oil contracts as a means for Chinese companies to buy oil and gas in their own currency, thereby avoiding exposure to foreign currency fluctuations and firing a shot across the bow of US dollar supremacy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. And if China can't withstand these US counterattacks, its efforts to build a multipolar financial world could, um, well, fall flat. It's a really complex picture.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. And if China can't withstand these U S counterattacks, its efforts to build a multipolar financial world could, um, well, fall flat. It's a really complex picture.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If China can withstand US counterattacks, its efforts will lay the financial groundwork for the emergence of a multipolar world.
